div.opener:
H B the younger desires me
to give you her very best love
& to thank you for all your
great kindness to her - She
says you are indeed very
kind to her tho' she has
never actually worshipped
you -
Tuesday - I have
just heard that
without doubt
Dr Brinkley is to be the
new Bishop - I can't
help being surprised
at his accepting
what must so much
separate him from
the science which has
always been his first
object - I fear that Mr
Pond & other astronoms
will say that he
wanted to get rid of
this parallax -
I have just been with
Mr & Mrs. Butler to the
Br. of Meath's & to Allente
They made me go
with them - I was
afraid of being de
trop detrop- They seem
to go on very well
together - but still
I cannot help wondering
at Harriet's having
liked him -
I believe your
eyes & can spectacles
will be tired reading
this letter - so I can
only beg you to forgive
your affect.te HB -
Black Castle Sept.r 17
My dear Francis
div.p:
I received your letter last Sunday, & that I might
not overpower you by too rapid a rejoinder I have wasted
a whole week to begin my answer - in the first place
thank you most heartily for writing a long letter to
Fanny Stewart - I think it will not only influence them
in their plans, but will calm her poor mind which
has of late been so feverish about coming home -
I cannot help feeling sometimes as if it was most
unnatural & hard hearted of me to advise her to stay away
- but indeed I have written like any Roman to her - & besides
I know it would be only changing from one poverty to another
& that she would have any little more comfort of her friend.
I begged of her to try one year more at least. - I have
had a letter from her since I wrote to you in which she says
that Tom though quite tired of the country was determined to
try it longer, & see if any thing would turn up through the
kindness of his friends. The Pastmastership has been negatived
in the Parliament - & as to the military road, their friend Col: Foster
told Tom that it is out of the question, for none but military
people will be employed - so that at present they have not any hope
even of employment - & are I suppose therefore more dispirited. It is curious
that Mr Ried who was the chief instigator of Tom's going to Canada should
now advise them to return - he has assured Fanny that on their income wh
is £100 a year they could live more comfortably at home than in Canada -
He also tells Fanny that Tom's property in Ireland will rise much in a few years
- but how can this be - it consists of leases from L. ' Donegal, which they have not
received - & the whole income for the number of years they still will possess it
would not amount I understand to the debts & interest which it is to pay
Fanny says that Tom will not tell her how it is circumstanced & will
seldom speak of his affairs to her - it is a curious thing that in the 4 years
they have been away, Tom has never heard from the trustees who were to manage
his property, any particulars of what they have done - nor have they even told
him what sum they received for his mills which were sold! He has written now
now to enquire - what little might be done with his property in Ireland
is not done - & no one here will make enquiry - all say they have no
right to enquire at all into the management of these assignees
But after all, it is only a sort of dream or castle building in the air
to talk of coming over next year - for he has not completed the
payment of his fees nor cleared all he is bound to do - & till this
is done his deed cannot be taken out by which his land will be
secured to him. This he told her himself the last letter mentioned
I fear that poor Fanny will have but a miserable winter
altogether - between his grumpy silence & irritability - & the
extraordinary illness of her best maid, - and I cannot
help being uneasy about her own health which must
suffer I fear from anxiety vexation & over work - without
one little counterbalancing delight of feeling that his love
& his tenderness were unchanged
They have had bears there & at Mr Reid's lately - seizing
the pigs which they nearly killed, but they were driven off
luckily in time to save them - The bears came again in
the night & ate & trampled great part of an uncommonly
fine field of wheat all in ear of Toms - & I am much afraid
they will attack the children some times. I feel greatly &
truly obliged to you for writing to her so fully - & I know your
letter will be the greatest comfort to her she loves you so much
& rests so much on your judgement.
Thank you for condescending to tell me your sentiments fully
in regard to your opinion & advice relative to Lovell's going abroad
I assure you I am most grateful whenever you can find time
to tell me any of your ideas or explain them to me - & it has besides
the advantage of preventing all mistakes about you - for
there are many who, not sufficiently aware of my stupidity
& insignificance, expect me to know your sentiments, &
think that you probably have explained yourself or whatever
the point in question, may be, to me & then people mistake what I say & think it your opinion. - In this case I shall
feel the immediate effect probably - for in any conversation
I have with Maria about it - I shall now go on sure grounds
as I shall rest on your opinion. Edgeworths town alas will
never be what it was - & I fear much that all the efforts
to preserve it as the centre & point of union of the family will
fail - & sometimes I doubt butwhether the absence of the person who
is the nominal head of the family, will not hasten the ruin of the
whole. Yet on the other hand I do think it would be for the happiness
of all if he could go abroad. Maria feels much at the Decision
for his going or staying depending on her - for however her
judgement may be in favour of his going; - her heart rises against
the idea of condemning him to wander about about as he says an
outcast from the family.
I asked them as to the money to be had at low interest
-He said he could not tell exactly any person to
apply to, but that when he was in Eng.Englandd last year he had
offers of it from various people - & the manner in which
you can easily procure it - is by advertising for money at
low interest on Irish Mortgages. Mr Hughes his agent at
ChiltenhamCheltenham advertised, & he had innumerable offers at 4
- & at our & a quarter prct. - He says if you advertise in
London for it, you will find it very easily procured - This was all
I could learn for you about it -
What a very very provoking thing your not having
received Mr Croker's letter - one day's delay would have
have given you a profitable employment - & one which would
not have detained you too long from Alicia -
& would have at least given me the pleasure
of thinking that wherever you were you
were within reach, & that some odd chance might bring
you to me - And now observe, & profit by this experience
my dear Captain, if you had allowed one day to poor
old Allens town, to wander about with me in my ancient
haunts, & to indulge Bess & all your admirers there, You
would have had your letter in right time - you would
have had your purse somewhat filled - & we should
- at least poor little I should have had one whole day passed
with you there to think of ever after - Since 1804 we never were
in that house together for more than a night - 22 Years!
- a long & varied time to look back upon - Joy & bitter grief - Gloom
& brightness - failure & success - all appear in ones revisited
view of such a time - but in all these lights & shadows, our friendship
remains unclouded unbroken & you are still as you say in
your last command to me, my old friend & brother & Master -
And when the vanities & flatterys of life have passed away, it
will be one pleasure at least to us to look back on the unchanged
affection of our whole lives - to me indeed greater than it can be to you,
because I know well my worthless inferiority -
I met a lady the other day, who on hearing my name asked if I had any
relation in the navy - I proudly said I had a brother - "I used to see him
frequently said she, many years ago. - When he was in London waiting
for employment after a hessie action he had performed -
I was then young & very romantic, & I had the greatest admiration
of him - I thought him the first of heroes" - I said I would tell
you of her recollection of you - "oh no said she - tho' he frequently
breakfasted at my brother's, I never scarcely ventured to speak to
him" - he would not remember me I am sure; - I admired him as
a hero without venturing to speak to him" - Her brother was Mr Henry
Alexander - She is sister to the Bp.Bishop of Meath - & is now wife of Major Scott
of the Artillery & lives at Woolwich - have you any recollection of her
- she never could have been handsome - How you did win
all hearts - dear old hero! I was very glad to come here just now to meet the Butlers. - I must say
Harriet looks & seems very happy & very satisfied - She is in better looks
a great deal - & has got back her colour which had gone so much when
we saw her - She is quite at ease & as much herself as ever - just the
same lovely quick animated creature - & so kind - She is at all times
so kind to me - I believe they will go to their own home the end of
this week - & I hope it may be a happy home, for she deserves it
We left Allenstown on Saturday & I suppose we shall be here for a week
or ten days at the utmost, & then go to Philpotstown & thence to town
Sophy Fox wanted us a very kindly to go to Cloonagh but it is getting late
in the year now, & Bess is now inclined to go home - she got at a great
cold I am sorry to say. Thank you for undertaking Anne's case - I will
send it you as soon as I can -
How miraculously the sea air has improved Honora - another
instance of your good judgement - I am sure if at last you should
prove a little conceited it would be no wonder - She is overflowing with
gratitude to you for making her try its effects - She is quite a different
My dear Francis, you would be happy indeed
could you see how happy Mr. & Mrs Butler are
- She is now all her own gay natural self with
all the ease of a mind satisfied with the present
and not anxious about the future - It appears
to great advantage, - no longer yet looks as if he were
going to be hanged - has recovered his powers
of conversation & is quite the popular bridegroom
here - Harriet pleased & was pleased with all
her husbands relations which he told me with great delight
